metadata.synopsis: Odessa Carter (Whoopi Goldberg) needs to get to work as a nanny in the home of the affluent Miriam Thompson (Sissy Spacek), but she refuses to take the bus. Odessa is participating in the Montgomery bus boycott, protesting against the inequality between blacks and whites, so Miriam decides to offer Odessa a ride to work every day. Though the community and Miriam's husband (Dwight Schultz) insist she not get involved, the relationship between Miriam and Odessa has already changed for the better.

reviews: There are enough strengths to make the whole movie feel a little bit more pedestrian for not being able to capitalise on them more.
The understated passion of The Long Walk Home sneaks up on your emotions.
Moving Civil Rights story heavy on "N" word but uplifting.
Suffers from too much focus on the white characters, but still an important story, respectfully told.
An excellent performance from Whoopi Goldberg. A memorable moment in cinema.
Drama set in Alabama during the 1955 bus boycott proclaiming that racial equality cannot be eased into effortlessly; it requires the rigors of change and commitment.
The Long Walk Home is a powerful and affecting film, so well played by Goldberg and Spacek that we understand not just the politics of the time but the emotions as well.
